title-group.article-title: Arthrodesis of the wrist with bone autograft and Hoffmann external fixation

abstract.p: We report a series of 29 cases of wrist arthrodesis using a radiometacarpal half-frame or triangular Hoffmann configuration, bone autograft, and relocation of a retinacular rectangular flap under the extensor tendons to prevent adhesions. No splint or plaster cast has been used. Early active motion of the fingers was encouraged. The average duration of follow-up was 4 years. Bone healing was obtained in 27 patients after 104 days on average. All patients regained full finger movements and rotation of the forearm. Nine patients were reassessed on average 7.2 years after the arthrodesis: the VAS for pain at rest was 2.4/10, the DASH score 33/100, the grip strength 75% of the contralateral side on average.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Total wrist arthrodesis was initially indicated for treating tuberculosis (Ely, 1920) or severe contractures resulting from poliomyelitis, spasticity or Volkman’s ischaemia. The operation is presently reserved as a salvage procedure for painful degenerative post-traumatic osteoarthrosis after failure of previous surgical reconstructions, including arthroplasty (Rizzo et al., 2011). It also remains the procedure of choice in certain conditions, including stage IV Kienböck’s disease and advanced destructive rheumatoid arthritis (Toma et al., 2007; Trieb, 2008). Total wrist fusion can be considered a success only if the patient regains powerful, stable and pain-free hand grip with unlimited pronation–supination and finger motion.

The surgical technique is still controversial. The current standard is rigid fixation by a dedicated dorsal plate, after resection of the hyaline cartilage of the opposing surfaces of the radioscaphoid, radiolunate, scapholunate, scaphocapitate and capitolunate joints, with iliac crest or locally harvested bone autografting (Adey et al., 2005; Hasting et al., 1996; Toma et al., 2007; Wright and McMurtry, 1983). Several authors have recommended leaving the carpometacarpal joints unfused (Campbell and Keokarn, 1964), whereas others include these joints in the arthrodesis. Instead of plate fixation, the osteosynthesis can be done using staples and screws (Viegas et al., 1989), by intramedullary Steinman pins (Papaioannou and Dickson, 1982; Viegas et al., 1989), intramedullary rods (Clayton and Ferlic, 1984; Mannerfelt and Malmsten, 1971; Rauhaniemi et al., 2005; Toma et al., 2007) or multiple Kirschner wires (Campbell and Keokarn, 1964). Intramedullary techniques are particularly indicated in cases of ankylosing rheumatoid arthritis in which rapid bone fusion is expected. In 1993 our group proposed the use of external fixation in wrist fusion (Schuind and Burny, 1995; Schuind et al., 1993) and it has also been recently advocated by Vekris et al. (2010).

There are several limitations to the techniques of plate or intramedullary fixation for wrist arthrodesis. The precise position of arthrodesis may vary according to the needs of the individual patient depending on the priority of power grip or precision pinch activity, or the status of the contralateral wrist, for example in bilateral fusions in rheumatoid arthritis (Rauhaniemi et al., 2005; Toma et al., 2007). This position is imposed by the implant, e.g. a neutral position in the case of a straight plate or intramedullary fixation, or 10° extension with neutral radial–ulnar inclination if the surgeon chooses the AO ASIF precontoured plate (Synthes, Bettlach, Switzerland). Occasionally correct positioning of a plate may be quite difficult, due to the preoperative wrist deformity. Internal fixation techniques are contraindicated when there is previous or active infection, poor bone stock or insufficient skin coverage.

Complications of wrist arthrodesis are reported to be relatively frequent and serious. They include postoperative infection, nonunion, implant breakage (even of the plate) or late stress fractures of the radius or metacarpals (Rauhaniemi et al., 2005; Toma et al., 2007; Zachary and Stern, 1995). Finger stiffness is frequent, usually as a result of extensor tendon impingement on the underlying plate (De Smet et al., 2005). Occasionally, ruptures of extensor tendons occur (Toma et al., 2007). Indeed, plate removal is frequently necessary, when bone healing has been achieved (Toma et al., 2007). Limitations of pronation and supination are related to associated distal radioulnar joint degeneration or instability. Many patients complain of persistent pain (Gaisne et al., 1991; Houshian and Schrøder, 2001; Sagerman and Palmer, 1996). This may have several causes, including nonunion (of the whole wrist, or second/third carpometacarpal joints), impaction of the ulnar dome or ulnar styloid on the triquetrum when there is decreased carpal height (Trumble et al., 1988), secondary degenerative osteoarthrosis of the carpometacarpal joints (in particular, the second, third and fifth joints), extensor tenosynovitis on the underlying dorsal plate (Adey et al., 2005), carpal tunnel syndrome (Rauhaniemi et al., 2005) or Complex Regional Pain Syndrome (CRPS). For these reasons, many authors consider that mobility preserving procedures such as proximal row carpectomy or arthroplasty are preferable to wrist arthrodesis (Cavaliere and Chung, 2008; De Smet, 2007).

In an effort to overcome some of the problems associated with wrist arthrodesis using plate fixation, the authors have developed a technique of wrist fusion which combines bridging bone autograft, preservation of the carpal height, and Hoffmann external fixation, with precise positioning the fused wrist in the position judged optimal to the patient’s needs. We have used this technique since 1983.

sec.title: Patients and methods
sec.p: Thirty-three consecutive cases of total wrist arthrodesis using Hoffmann external fixation have been done but four cases have been excluded from this report as being too recent. Nine of the patients have been reviewed by an independent observer in 2008, to obtain the VAS score for persistent pain, the DASH measurement of disability, subjective patient satisfaction, the 400-point function scale (Schuind et al., 2003) and the maximal static grip test using the Jamar dynamometer. This review was done after a mean follow-up of 7.2 years (median, 7 years; range, 1–16 years). In addition to the clinical assessment, new radiographs were obtained, to establish the state of fusion, to measure the carpal height and to diagnose possible secondary degenerative osteoarthritic changes. Twenty patients could not be reassessed, either because they had died for reasons unrelated to the wrist arthrodesis (six patients), because of a change of residency (three patients), because they were unwilling to participate in this review (four patients), or for various other reasons. For these 20 patients, data on healing and complications are based on the prospective clinical follow-up at our external fixation clinic (observer: F.B.), with an average follow-up duration of 4 years (median, 2 years; range, 6 months – 19 years). The diagnosis of bone healing was based on the clinical observation of complete absence of radiocarpal motion and radiological evidence (using CT from 2002) of bony bridges between the bones. All radiological images were reviewed by an experienced radiologist and an experienced orthopaedic surgeon (F.B.).

sec.title: Surgical technique
sec.p: The surgical approach is through a dorsal midline incision. Care is taken to avoid devascularizing the skin flaps. The third compartment is opened, followed by the fourth and fifth compartments, raising an ulnarly based rectangular retinacular flap. Lateral and medial reflection of the extensor tendons allows good visualization of the dorsal radius and carpal bones. A 1–1.5 cm deep trench is then dug between the radius, scaphoid, lunate, capitate and trapezoid bones, extending to the bases of the second and third metacarpal bones. No effort is made to remove the cartilage between the carpal bones, maintaining the preoperative carpal height. Then 3 mm Hoffmann APEX external fixation pins (Stryker Trauma, Selzach, Switzerland) are implanted in the radius and metacarpal bones. At the radius, two pins are usually used, taking care to avoid the dorsal sensory branch of the radial nerve by placing them dorsoradially 7 cm above the radiocarpal joint. The second metacarpal pins are also dorsoradially oriented, avoiding the extensor tendons. If the stability obtained with a simple radius to second metacarpal transarticular radiometacarpal half-frame is judged to be not sufficient by the surgeon, additional pins are implanted dorsoulnarly in the fifth metacarpal, allowing the construction of a radius to second and fifth metacarpal triangular configuration (Figure 1). The position of the wrist fusion is carefully chosen, according to preoperative planning and the patient’s requirements. It was in 20–30° extension and 10–20° ulnar inclination in most cases. Corticocancellous bone autograft harvested from the anterior iliac crest are impacted as bone chips within the radiometacarpal bone trench. The retinacular flap is then relocated palmarly to the extensor tendons, in order to prevent the development of postoperative adhesions. The wounds are closed with suction drainage.

sec.title: Postoperative care
sec.p: Postoperative shoulder, elbow, forearm and finger mobilization is started immediately after operation, initially under the supervision of a specialized physiotherapist. Hygiene is essential. The care of the pin skin exit sites is standardized. We recommend pin site disinfection with Hibitane alcohol 70% once a day. Showering and bathing are allowed as soon as the surgical wounds have healed. If there is pin track infection, oral antibiotics are given for 10 days in addition to local disinfection. External fixation is discontinued in the outpatient clinic when solid bone healing is observed on postoperative radiographs. No additional postoperative immobilization is used at any time in the postoperative period.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: There were 19 men and 10 women, with an average age of 47 years at surgery (median, 44 years; range 21–77 years). The indications for wrist fusion are detailed in Table 1. Seventeen patients presented after one or more previous wrist operations (Table 2). A triangular configuration was chosen in 26 cases and a simple half frame radius to second metacarpal configuration in three patients. Associated procedures included reconstruction of ruptured extensor tendons (two cases), Darrach procedure (two cases), carpal tunnel decompression (one case) and ulnar neurolysis at the elbow (one case).

sec.p: The early postoperative complications included one haematoma in a patient on anticoagulant medications after heart valve replacement, one partial necrosis of skin in a patient who had had multiple operations, one transient hypoaesthesia in the dermatome of the dorsal branch of the radial nerve, and one extensor tendon rupture over the distal ulnar stump in a patient with rheumatoid arthritis who had had a Darrach procedure. This last patient had a stabilization of the ulnar stump and an extensor tendon graft 4 weeks after the wrist arthrodesis. There were two cases of moderate CRPS, which resolved after removal of the external fixator at the time of bone healing. Minor pin-track infection was seen in nine patients, and always resolved with oral antibiotic treatment.

Solid bone healing was obtained in 27 patients after a mean period of external fixation of 104 days (median, 105 days; range 61–137 days). Two patients had to be reoperated after 6 and 14 months using the same technique, because the CT scan demonstrated incomplete bone healing (one at midcarpal, the other at the carpometacarpal level). All patients finally achieved solid bone union. There were also two other reoperations for distal radioulnar joint pain (Darrach procedure). In total, five patients had a secondary operation. All patients regained full finger flexion–extension and forearm pronation–supination. There were no cases of extensor tenosynovitis and no cases of carpal tunnel syndrome. No case of secondary metacarpal fracture has been observed. One patient developed a diaphyseal forearm fracture, 19 years after the arthrodesis, as a consequence of a severe sporting injury.

At the reassessment of nine patients in 2008 after a mean follow-up of 7.2 years the following were recorded: a mean VAS for pain at rest of 2.4/10 (SD 2.7); a mean DASH score of 33/100 (SD 20/100); good hand function (86% of normal hand function on the 400-point score); and a maximal grip strength of 75% (SD 26%) of the contralateral side on average (median, 85%; range 22–104%). The mean carpal height ratio at follow-up was 0.45 (SD 0.03). This was an average reduction of 15% compared to the average normal value of 53% (Schuind et al., 1992). The patients rated their result as excellent (five patients), good (two patients) or fair (two patients). No result was considered by a patient to be bad.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Bridging external fixation is a standard technique for treating comminuted fractures of the distal radius, allowing the maintenance of a good reduction and leading to acceptable functional results (Fernandez et al., 1983; Schuind and Burny, 1995; Schuind et al., 1989). It is especially indicated in the case of open fractures and in fractures occurring in polytrauma patients. Radiometacarpal external fixation has also been proposed for some carpometacarpal fractures (Büchler et al., 1991; Schuind and Burny, 1988: Schuind et al., 1993; Schuind and Burny, 1995) and in partial carpal arthrodesis, the aim being to restore the carpal height (Schuind et al., 1988; Schuind and Burny, 1995). It is the technique of choice to apply prolonged distraction on the carpus, for example during revascularization procedures of the lunate in early Kienböck’s disease (Schuind et al., 1993; Schuind and Burny, 1995; Schuind et al, 2008). In total wrist arthrodesis, external fixation offers significant advantages over conventional techniques with osteosynthesis by plate or intramedullary fixation. Stable fixation is obtained, allowing unrestrained early active mobilization of the whole upper extremity, including the fingers. Indeed, as there is no orthosis or plaster cast, the patient can immediately use his/her hand, while the external fixator is in place, which is of course the best way to prevent postoperative finger stiffness and CRPS. To prevent possible tendon adhesions, we relocate a retinacular flap deep to the extensor tendons, which is impossible to do when a thick plate is applied on the dorsum of the wrist. Hoffmann external fixation is very versatile, allowing fine tuning of the final position of the arthrodesis. This position may be possibly determined by wearing a test wrist splint before operation. In manual workers we recommend 30° dorsal flexion and 10° ulnar inclination, as this position gives maximal grip strength (O’Driscoll et al., 1992). In the absence of a rigid plate, the risk of stress fractures of the radius or metacarpal is quite reduced. This complication, which sometimes occurs after plate fixation, was only seen in one case in this series, high above the arthrodesis, 19 years after the operation, following serious trauma. External fixation is especially indicated in patients in whom the arthrodesis is necessary after infectious joint destruction (four cases) or complex open carpal trauma with massive contamination (two cases in this series). We observed no case of later deep infection. External fixation may also be a solution for the difficult problem of revision after a failed arthroplasty (Figure 2).

sec.p: The healing rate was high in this series. Although the technique of creating a dorsal radiocarpal bone bridge was insufficient in two cases, we feel that the technique of bone bridging allows the maintenance of the preoperative carpal height. This could be important, not only for optimal muscle function, but also to prevent impaction of the ulnar dome or ulnar styloid on the triquetrum. Preserving the palmar part of the carpal bones prevents the impaction of bone graft fragments within the carpal tunnel. Interestingly enough, there has been no case of carpal tunnel syndrome in this series, while this complication is not unfrequent after other techniques. Median nerve compression might be related to diminished carpal height, prominent dorsopalmar screws and/or to palmar protrusion of some bone autograft fragments within the carpal tunnel.

The main drawback of external fixation is the possibility of pin site infection, occurring in almost one third of our patients. This is obviously significant but seems to us to be acceptable, since all infections were transient, resolving after oral antibiotherapy. No patient had to be readmitted to hospital, no external fixator had to be removed or changed because of an infection, and there has been no case of late intraosseous abscess.

The majority of patients were satisfied with their wrist arthrodesis. However, as in other series of wrist fusion (Adey et al., 2005; De Smet, 2007; De Smet and Truyen, 2003; Rauhaniemi et al., 2005), complete pain relief was rare, and the patients had significant limitations in activities of daily living as demonstrated by the alterations in DASH and the 400-point score.
